summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Christian Everdell and federal prosecutors regarding scheduling a Rule 412/Daubert hearing and confirming trial length estimates for the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The parties coordinate on drafting a joint letter to the court.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, coordinating with prosecutors on trial scheduling and drafting a joint letter to the court.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Federal prosecutor copied on email correspondence regarding trial scheduling in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense attorney copied on email correspondence regarding trial scheduling in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

connections.description: Defense attorney and prosecutor communicating about trial scheduling and court filings in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
Both are defense attorneys working on the Ghislaine Maxwell case, copied on the same correspondence.

events.title: Potential Rule 412/Daubert Hearing
events.description: Possible date for a hearing on Rule 412 (rape shield law) and Daubert (expert testimony) motions in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Preferred Rule 412/Daubert Hearing
events.description: Defense's preferred date for the Rule 412/Daubert hearing in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

keyFacts: The defense maintained a 6-week trial length estimate for Ghislaine Maxwell's trial despite court rulings on motions in limine.
Prosecutors estimated their case-in-chief would take 3-4 weeks.
Parties were coordinating to schedule a Rule 412/Daubert hearing, with the defense preferring November 10, 2021.
The correspondence shows ongoing pretrial preparations and coordination between defense and prosecution teams.
